model.name: Model for hepatic S -> P + T metabolism in the liver

notes.body:
Model for hepatic metabolism of substrate (S) to product (P) and toxic byproduct (T) encoded in SBML format.
The model consists of of a single liver compartment with single metabolic conversion reaction which converts the substrate S to the product P and a toxic byproduct T S -> P + T. The product P can be exported from the liver with the toxic side product T being confined to the liver.
If the hepatic concentration of the toxic substance T reaches a critical threshold necrosis is initiated.
version: 0.6.0
Changelog
version 0.6.0
inflows and outflows for model coupling added
version 0.5.4
typo fix: TDETOX_Km_napqi -> TDETOX_Km_T
version 0.5.3
fixed switching thresholds for C++ export
additional annotations and documentation
removed source reactions
version 0.5
updated gamma thresholds
version 0.1
initial model version based on minimal apap model

rdf:li.vCard4:organization-name: Humboldt-University Berlin, Institute for Theoretical Biology

body.p: Molecular entity which serves as input for an enzymatic reaction that generates a product.
Product which is generated by an enzymatic reaction.
Enzyme that catalyzes the reactions of S -> P + T (e.g. cytochrome P450).

parameter.name: flag to change rate of metabolism

body.p: Set to 1 if TPM simulation, set to 0 for ODE simulation.

parameter.name: position within the lobulus in [0, 1] (pp, pv)

body.p: pattern: 0: constant (constant over position) 1: linear_increase (increase from periportal 0 to perivenious 1) 2: sharp_periveneous (high periveneous 1, low otherwise 0) 3: linear_decrease (decrease from periportal 1 to perivenious 0) 4: sharp_periportal (high periportal 1, low otherwise 0) 5: random

parameter.name: random value set via initial assignment

body.p: Damage status of the cell. Either alive or necrotic (dead).
debug parameter to track time in model coupling

parameter.name: Vmax for S to P + T conversion
Km for S to P + T conversion

body.p: Same protein amount for different patterns based on 2D lobulus geometry. Patterns are scaled via the scaling factors.
debug rule to track time in model coupling
